Portfolio redesign

Portfolio redesign

Designing my portfolio

It is almost a mandatory exercise in the field, every designer has to build over the year a portfolio where they can showcase the best of their work. One year ago as I started my interaction design Bachelor's degree I built the first version of mine.

Now one year have passed and as my skills have improved I started to see all the problems in my old portfolio.

Researches

Before starting to draft on paper I made some researches about Ux design portfolios. The excellent site Cofolios, as well as the advice from Charles Perinet, helped me to set up a list of all the milestones I needed to reach in order to build a good portfolio.

Design

I came across many iterations before finding one that looked good enough to start producing it. I wanted something minimalistic and easy to upgrade if needed in the future.

Illustrations

One problem I faced during the iterative process that was much time I was stuck in my technical side. I wanted to show a beautiful webgl background or P5.js sketch that I made. My portfolio was lacking soul and colors, that's why I added some handcrafted illustrations to bring life to the page. This choice is really personal and I have both good and bad feedback about it.

Quick introduction

I wanted the recruiters or visitors to dive into my projects as quickly as possible, so I only made a really quick introduction on the landing page

Simple navigation

I wanted the navigation to be as simple as possible. If my own website is not easy to navigate I can't pretend to be a good UX designer. The site is only one level deep and the user can come back home at any time.

Understanding that recruiters have to quickly get into the project I chose to put other project suggestion at the end of each project. In mobile where the user has to scroll more all projects and a back to home button following the suggestions.

Development

For the development, I choose a modern stack composed of node.js, Laravel and Vue.js.

Backend

I build a simple backend in PHP/Mysql by making use of the LUMEN framework. It is a lightweight alternative of Laravel. It can communicate with the front end by a simple restful API.

Front-end

One of the goals of this portfolio was to build my own project editor working with the API as my own personal CMS. Used to markdown writing experience I wanted to stay as close as I could to this kind of editing but using custom component to leverage the power of Vue.js.

My choice was to build an editor based on Tiptap, a really nice editor made on top of the widely used ProseMiror.

Result

I am really happy with how much it has improved over time. The feedback from professionals, friends, and teachers have been really valuable. I still have a lot of work to do to implement all the features I already have designed but I have the feeling it's in a good way.

Problems

One big problem I facing is SEO and performance on low-end devices. At the time I started the project it wasn't much of concern but with the growing codebase, it becomes more and more problematic.

As the whole website is rendered trough javascript the bots from search engine struggle to crawl it. One solution could be to server-side render it but it would again need new functionalities developed. The path I am taking now is to use static site generation using Nuxt.js to pre-generate pages.

The API is very convenient to work with compared to writing the projects by the end and I really like the editor I developed for the projects. But that add too much complexity to the website. When it will be ready for static rendering I will switch from the editor to plain markdown files with custom elements on it.

You can help me!

You are currently on one of the latest version of my portfolio and I am very curious about what you think about it. If you want to share feedback with me, please contact me at simon.renault.pro@gmail.com
